displayed_text: Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well- Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it.
